title.narrative: Desert Locust Response and Resilience Building in Ethiopia

description.narrative: Beneficiaries of the project are youth (females and males), women and men, poor female headed households, PLW and elders from the poor and vulnerable pastoralists, farmers and agro-pastoralists communities. Overall, 49,762 vulnerable individuals will directly benefit from the proposed project (the average household size is 6). Additional 99524 individuals also will benefit indirectly, bringing the number of direct and indirect beneficiaries to 149,286 individuals.

Development goal: Contribute to 8,294 households (49,762 people) in Ethiopia recover from the desert locust invasion and build their preparedness and resilience to shocks and crises
Project objective 1: Households of the targeted communities have rehabilitated from the immediate impacts of the desert locust invasion
Project objective 2: Target communities' adaptive capacity to withstand natural and human-made shocks is enhanced

The humanitarian situation in Ethiopia is complex. The desert locust adds to multiple humanitarian shocks since last year, such recurrent droughts and poor rainfall (e.g. 2015-2018), floods (e.g. 2019 and 2020), conflicts, macroeconomic challenges, vulnerability, and most recently the global COVID-19 pandemic. Two-thirds of the past 12 (67%) rainy seasons have been below average across the target areas. Where above-average rains occurred, flooding has destroyed livelihoods, services and infrastructure, and caused displacement, especially in 2019 and 2020. The poor pastoralists, agro-pastoralists and farmers in the target areas are not getting the agricultural inputs and technology to ensure household food security. Insecurity, inter-communal violence and military confrontations damaged livelihoods, caused displacement and undermined humanitarian access. The absence of job opportunities for agricultural labor due to loss of crops by desert locust damage and COVID-19 is also undermining food security. Access to food through markets has been compromised due to high inflation rates deterioration of the local currency, and spike in staple foods & essential commodities prices. Despite the gradual ease on movement restrictions, COVID-19 still poses a threat on households’ health and economic capability. Key impacts of COVID-19 include, loss of income earning opportunities, and disrupting trade activities. The desert locust has damaged extensive areas of crops and pasture and browse since 2019, compromising the food security situation for the affected households. The rapid incursion of desert locusts has resulted in significant cropland losses and jeopardized the livelihoods of smallholder farmers who depend on crops. The current desert locust plague poses additional threat to the food security of millions of people, and likely to add further stress to an already fragile livelihood and food security situation. According to Updated 2020 Ethiopia Humanitarian Response Plan, an estimated 20.9 million people (current and projected) are facing severe acute food insecurity and in need of assistance in Ethiopia. The updated number of people in need (PIN) due to non-Covid-19 related crises (including new displacements and desert locust affected people) is now 10.6 million persons, and 10.3 million are the projected number of people in need due to COVID-19 pandemic (combined food and health related needs). The underlying cause(s) of food insecurity in the project districts are population pressure, drought, shortage of farmland, weakening food production capacity, poor farming technologies and post-harvest loss outbreak of plant and animal disease, shortage of alternative income. Pastoralists, agro-pastoralists and farmers are heavily dependent on livestock and crop. This strong dependence on one source of income makes them extremely vulnerable.

participating-org.narrative: Development and Inter-Church Aid Commission - Ethiopian Orthodox Church

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Project Specific Indicators
Number of farmers accessed the available improved agricultural inputs
Hygiene promotion (Awareness)
WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
CSH-I1: Number of people benefitting from unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers

description.narrative: Unconditional transfers are provided to beneficiaries without the recipient having to do anything in return in order to receive the assistance . Unrestricted transfers can be used entirely as the recipient chooses i.e. there are no restrictions on how the transfer is spent (Definitions of CALP). It can be delivered e.g. through local banks, shops, traders, local money transfer companies, remittance companies and post offices in either one or several instalments.

title.narrative: FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: The humanitarian response was Appropriate

description.narrative: Appropriateness is assessed according to the SPHERE standards. A response is considered to be appropriateness based on needs assessment, taking account of rights, needs, culture, age, gender, disabilities and context, and equity (non-discrimination and equal access.

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Corporate Indicators
Number of people with increased access to good quantity and quality of food through own production or income

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Number of unemployed youth successfully supported into (self)employment

description.narrative: Number of youth who have secured employment, comparing from before the intervention to after (baseline to Endline). NB Both waged employment and self-employment (i.e. are employed by someone else or have started their own business)

title.narrative: Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Number of households with more diversified livelihoods (income generation)

description.narrative: Number of households that have been able to diversify their primary livelihood through Cordaid interventions on this field. Diversification here means the process by which rural families construct a diverse portfolio of activities and social support capabilities in order to survive and to improve their standards of living.

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SU)

description.narrative: Number of people who have benefitted (directly or indirectly) through a Cordaid Sustainable Livelihoods Intervention

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.

title.narrative: Saving Lives Project Specific Indicators
Number of hygiene kits distributed
